column3: @sanket1729 @apoelstra may be interested too

This looks great. To get the concept ACK I'm wondering what the arguments against are. I think (I may be mistaken) these are broadly long term motivations and sketched out roadmap-like issues.\n\n1) Does Bitcoin Core *need* to be able to recognize Miniscript in the future? Are the future upsides sufficiently material to introduce it? Presumably Miniscript could always be translated to Script ext

@jachiang

Very nice to see another Miniscript implementation! I love Miniscript! :)

You might want to check your Python implementation for the following issues I've reported in the C++ and Rust implementations:
* [Issues reported in the C++ implementation (7 of which I would consider bugs)](https://github.com/sipa/miniscript/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue+author%3Apracticalswift+)
Concept ACK. Moving these high level questions to a RFC (#18040) so as not to hold up review of the details of this PR. https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/17975#issuecomment-577095603
Concept ACK
Apologies for the delay updating this PR. \n\nf8a30b4c7 includes rebase and changes suggested by reviewers so far.

Another option here which might not be too bad in the scheme of things would be to check in a WASM blob that is gitian built of e.g. rust miniscript, and then call it using a wasm runtime https://github.com/wasmerio/wasmer-python\n\nthe main benefit being we don't have to check in yet another implementation of miniscript to maintain as miniscript evolves, we can use the rust or c++ one today, an

> the main benefit being we don't have to check in yet another implementation of miniscript to maintain as miniscript evolves, we can use the rust or c++ one today, and when the C++ becomes merged & available as an RPC we can drop it.\n\nIn the absence of a formal, (mechanizable) specification of Miniscript (MS), separate implementations have higher chances of finding bugs or problems than a sin
should be `=` rather than `+=` in two lines above, otherwise `child_is_e` will be converted to int and will always be `>= 1`
why not `child.t.name.startswith('WRAP_')` ?
That's much better. Thx.
Excellent catch. Thank you for review.

Please change this to "The Bitcoin Core developers" or add your name on line 105 in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/contrib/devtools/copyright_header.py\n\nOtherwise it will get overridden by the copyright-headers script
Thank you for the review and tip, will gladly amend copyright header as you suggested!

I think this should be ` prop_str += "f" if child_x.p.s or child_y.p.f else "" ` . Since the left child must have a base type`V`, it always has malleability property `f`. The above statement will make all `and_v` has property `f`. 
There is only one possible non-canonical dissat being [sat(X), dissat(Y)] which gives us self.f = `sx or fy`. 

One valid miniscript counter-example: `and_v(vc:pk
Should be `f=fxfy or sxfx or syfy`
Nit: Always `d`
Nit: Can never be f. Convert to an assertion?
I think this should be `or` instead of `and`?
unnecessary since it's already added at the start of function
This should never happen. Maybe replace it with an assertion?
Missing both V condition
f = fz and (sx or fy)
Should be if "Bdu" if is_B, otherwise ""
Yes absolutely! Thanks for the correction!
Ah yes, both V are from revised rules.
Got it, revised rules again :)
This was a mistake in encoding the property rules, thank you.
Should be type "V" if both "V".
nit: since we are returning `False` on invalid by conflicts below, let's just return `False` here too?
`W` conflicts with `n`, too.
It was renamed to `PK_K`
Now renamed to `MULTI`
(and `pk()` is now an alias for `c:pk_k()`)
`pk` is `x`
`pk_h` is `x` too
The `x` property isn't part of Miniscript itself and is an implementation detail of the C++ implem so i wonder if it's not clearer here to just use a boolean member to the `Node` class instead.
`after` and `older` are `x`
`and_v` should inherit `x` from `y` too
`and_b` is `x`
`and_n` (like `and_or`) is `x` too
`or_b` is `x` too
`or_d` is `x` too
`or_c` is `x`
`or_i` is `x`
`and_or` is `x`
`a:` is `x`
Should inherit `x` too
I think `t:` is `x` since it's `and_v(X, 1)` and `1` is `x`.
`d:` and `v:` are `x`
`j:` is `x`
`n` is `x` too
`l:` and `u:` should be `x` since `or_i()` is

You don't even actually use it actually (you match against `child_script[-1]` to check if you need to append `VERIFY`), so i'd say it's better to not have it at all (and therefore to ignore my comments regarding missing `x`s in the following commits).
That's super nit but i find it nicer to have an optional argument to the constructor instead of `from_string()` and use `__repr__` instead of `to_string()`
In addition to `pk` being renamed to `pk_k`, `pk` is now an alias for `c:pk_k` (so we need to keep matching this tag)
This function doesn't exist as of this commit.
`thresh` now supports `k == 1` or `k == n`.
Why `5`? It wouldn't match `1 <pk> 1 CMS`?
Why `k`? I think you rather want to iterate from `idx` to `expr_list_len-2` here?
This should check that `child_x` is `V` and y is `B`, `K` or `V`
This needs to check that `child_x` is `V`
Similarly as for `pk()`, `pkh()` is now an alias for `c:pk_h()`.

This should also check the other boundary imo:
```python
assert delay > 0 and delay < 2**31
```

This should check `Bdu` for `x` and either `B`, `K` or `V` for both y and z.
```python
        # X is Bdu; Y and Z are both B, K, or V
        assert all([getattr(child_x.p, pt) for pt in "Bdu"])
        for child in child_y, child_z:
            assert any([getattr(child.p, t) for t in "BKV"])
```
`x` must be `B` and `y` must be `W`..
or_b(X,Z) | X is Bd; Z is Wd
or_d(X,Z) | X is Bdu; Z is B
or_i(X,Z) | both are B, K, or V
`pk_h` is defined as taking a key, not a key hash. Different implementors have different opinions on this but we need to at least be able to parse pk_h() nodes with keys.
`X` must be `B`
X is Bdu; Z is V
X is Vz
X is Bn
X must be B, K or V
X is Bdu; Y and Z are both B, K, or V
